"**Coming Home** " is a song by American rapper and producer
[Diddy](/wiki/Sean_Combs "Sean Combs") and his group [Dirty
Money](/wiki/Dirty_Money_\(group\) "Dirty Money \(group\)"), from their debut
album _[Last Train to Paris](/wiki/Last_Train_to_Paris "Last Train to Paris")_
(2010). It was released on November 21, 2010, as the album's fourth single.
The contemporary [hip-hop](/wiki/Hip_hop_music "Hip hop music")
[pop](/wiki/Pop_music "Pop music") song was written by [Jermaine
Cole](/wiki/J._Cole "J. Cole"), Diddy, [Jay-Z](/wiki/Jay-Z "Jay-Z"), [Alex da
Kid](/wiki/Alex_da_Kid "Alex da Kid"), and [Skylar Grey](/wiki/Skylar_Grey
"Skylar Grey"). Kid and Jay-Z produced the song while Grey featured vocals on
the song's chorus. Jay-Z and Kid gifted the song to Diddy for _Last Train to
Paris_. [Autobiographically](/wiki/Autobiographical "Autobiographical")
written, "Coming Home" is inspired by moments in Diddy's life, the loss of his
close friend, [The Notorious B.I.G](/wiki/The_Notorious_B.I.G "The Notorious
B.I.G") and references to classic songs by [Dionne
Warwick](/wiki/Dionne_Warwick "Dionne Warwick"), [McFadden &
Whitehead](/wiki/McFadden_%26_Whitehead "McFadden & Whitehead"), and [Smokey
Robinson & the Miracles](/wiki/Smokey_Robinson_%26_the_Miracles "Smokey
Robinson & the Miracles").

Critics praised the redemptive ballad for the personal themes and lyrics which
were a snapshot of Diddy's life. Praise was also given for Grey's soft vocals
which complemented the warmth of the song. An accompanying music video,
directed by Rich Lee, follows the trio wandering through the desert in search
of home only to find burned belongings and the shell of a home. Singled out as
one of the album's highlights, "Coming Home" was promoted with live TV
performances including at the [American Music
Awards](/wiki/American_Music_Awards "American Music Awards") on November 21,
2010, the _[WWE Tribute to the Troops](/wiki/WWE_Tribute_to_the_Troops "WWE
Tribute to the Troops")_ concert, and the March 10, 2011 episode of _[American
Idol](/wiki/American_Idol "American Idol")_ which marked the first live
performance of the song featuring Skylar Grey. The song is also one of the
theme songs for [WWE WrestleMania 29](/wiki/WWE_WrestleMania_29 "WWE
WrestleMania 29").

To date, "Coming Home" is Diddy-Dirty Money's most successful single and the
highest charting single from _Last Train to Paris_. Aside from amassing one
million digital sales, it peaked at number eleven on the U.S. [_Billboard_ Hot
100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100") and number nine in Canada.
Internationally, the single topped both Belgium [Ultratip](/wiki/Ultratip
"Ultratip") charts and the [Swiss Singles Chart](/wiki/Swiss_Singles_Chart
"Swiss Singles Chart"), as well as reaching top five in the UK. This comes in
addition to breaking onto the A-playlists on British [urban music
radio](/wiki/BBC_Radio_1Xtra "BBC Radio 1Xtra") and [mainstream
radio](/wiki/BBC_Radio_1 "BBC Radio 1"), and topping the [UK R&B
Singles](/wiki/UK_R%26B_Chart "UK R&B Chart") chart for three consecutive
weeks.

## Inspiration and
composition[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Coming_Home_\(Diddy_%E2%80%93_Dirty_Money_song\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Inspiration and composition")]

"Coming Home" is a downtempo [hip-hop](/wiki/Hip-hop_music "Hip-hop music")
and [pop](/wiki/Pop_music "Pop music") song, that opens with a "simple piano
intro" and a "delicate vocal verse from [Skylar Grey](/wiki/Skylar_Grey
"Skylar Grey")".[2][3] It was written by [Diddy](/wiki/Sean_Combs "Sean
Combs"), [Skylar Grey](/wiki/Skylar_Grey "Skylar Grey"), [Jay-Z](/wiki/Jay-Z
"Jay-Z"), [J. Cole](/wiki/J._Cole "J. Cole"), and [Alex "da Kid"
Grant](/wiki/Alex_da_Kid "Alex da Kid"), and produced by [Jay-Z](/wiki/Jay-Z
"Jay-Z") and Grant.[4] When speaking to Kid about what he wanted, Diddy said,
"I want a beat that makes me feel like a white man in a basement in
[Atlanta](/wiki/Atlanta "Atlanta")".[5] Diddy later called "Coming Home" a
gift from Jay-Z and Kid.[6] According to the sheet music published at
Musicnotes.com, by [EMI Music Publishing](/wiki/EMI_Music_Publishing "EMI
Music Publishing"), the song was written in the key of [D major](/wiki/D_major
"D major") with a [time signature](/wiki/Time_signature "Time signature") of
[common time](/wiki/Common_time "Common time") and a [tempo](/wiki/Tempo
"Tempo") of 69 [beats per minute](/wiki/Beats_per_minute "Beats per minute").
It follows the basic [chord progression](/wiki/Chord_progression "Chord
progression") of [G](/wiki/G_\(musical_note\) "G \(musical
note\)")–[D](/wiki/D_\(musical_note\) "D \(musical
note\)")–[Bm](/wiki/B_\(musical_note\) "B \(musical
note\)")–[F♯m](/wiki/F%E2%99%AF_\(musical_note\) "F♯ \(musical note\)").[7]
Jayson Rodriguez of [MTV](/wiki/MTV "MTV") noted that the concept and theme of
the song were similar to events in Diddy's life, "referencing mistakes he has
made in the past and that he wants to put behind him." Rodriguez also noted
the song's tribute to [The Notorious B.I.G](/wiki/The_Notorious_B.I.G "The
Notorious B.I.G"), in the line "I miss you, B.I.G."[8] The chorus features
vocals from the group's female members, [Kalenna Harper](/wiki/Kalenna_Harper
"Kalenna Harper") and [Dawn Richard](/wiki/Dawn_Richard "Dawn Richard"), as
well as [background vocals](/wiki/Background_vocals "Background vocals") from
fellow [Bad Boy Records](/wiki/Bad_Boy_Records "Bad Boy Records") recording
artist [Cassie](/wiki/Cassie_Ventura "Cassie Ventura"). The trio use a vocal
range of [A3](/wiki/A_\(musical_note\) "A \(musical note\)")–A4. Grey also
sings some of the vocals, predominately during the song's opening
chorus.[4][7]

_[Rap-Up](/wiki/Rap-Up "Rap-Up")_ magazine reflected on the lyrics of the
song, calling them a personal reflection of Diddy's life and career thanks to
lines like "What am I ‘posed to do when the club lights come on/ It’s easy to
be Puff, but it’s harder to be Sean/ What if my twins ask why I ain’t married
their mom?"[9] Scott Schetler from [AOL Radio](/wiki/AOL_Radio "AOL Radio")
Blog noted how Diddy referenced a different popular song in each verse.[2]
Lamb particularly noted the strong autobiographical lyrics, and the references
to the 1979 hit song "[Ain't No Stoppin' Us
Now](/wiki/Ain%27t_No_Stoppin%27_Us_Now "Ain't No Stoppin' Us Now")" by
[McFadden & Whitehead](/wiki/McFadden_%26_Whitehead "McFadden &
Whitehead").[3] Other songs referenced include [Dionne
Warwick](/wiki/Dionne_Warwick "Dionne Warwick")'s "[A House Is Not a
Home](/wiki/A_House_Is_Not_a_Home_\(song\) "A House Is Not a Home \(song\)")"
(1964) and [Smokey Robinson & the
Miracles](/wiki/Smokey_Robinson_%26_the_Miracles "Smokey Robinson & the
Miracles")' "[The Tears of a Clown](/wiki/The_Tears_of_a_Clown "The Tears of a
Clown")" (1970).[10] Rodriguez said "Diddy do[es] some soul-searching in his
rhymes as the chorus echoes his need for salvation."[8]

Lamb compared the song to Diddy's early releases, saying that "'Coming Home'
[welcomes] Diddy back to the upper ranks of pop-oriented hip hop artists".[3]
Additionally, Diddy told MTV that although the track had
[autobiographical](/wiki/Autobiography "Autobiography") elements, it was part
of the album's "conceptual love story narrated by his character".[8] When
asked by [Live Lounge](/wiki/Live_Lounge "Live Lounge")'s Trevor Nelson what
"Coming Home" was based on, Diddy said:

> "Coming Home" goes to everybody out there who's going through a struggle or
> obstacle. I've been lost in life, I'm still lost in life in these sense of
> trying to find your way back to that person who your grandmother or father
> wanted you to be. Sometimes you get lost through drug addiction or you break
> up with up your partner or remission from cancer etc. you struggle to find
> your way back to yourself. That's what "Coming Home" is about.[11]

## Critical
reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Coming_Home_\(Diddy_%E2%80%93_Dirty_Money_song\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Critical reception")]

Upon release, "Coming Home" was generally met with a positive reception from
music critics, who praised the autobiographical lyrics and composition of
[Skylar Grey](/wiki/Skylar_Grey "Skylar Grey")'s vocals with the [Alex da
Kid](/wiki/Alex_da_Kid "Alex da Kid") and [Jay-Z](/wiki/Jay-Z "Jay-Z")
production. Becky Bain of [Idolator](/wiki/Idolator_\(website\) "Idolator
\(website\)") wrote, "We have to give some credit to Diddy (or Jay-Z, if he
did indeed write [the lyrics]) for dropping some truly introspective lyrics
instead of the usual not-so-subtle [Cîroc](/wiki/C%C3%AEroc "Cîroc") vodka
promotions.[12] Simon Vozick-Levinson from _[Entertainment
Weekly](/wiki/Entertainment_Weekly "Entertainment Weekly")_ agreed, and noted
"Coming Home" as one of _[Last Train to Paris](/wiki/Last_Train_to_Paris "Last
Train to Paris")_ ' highlights, saying it was a "must download" as the album's
only "redemptive ballad".[13] Jim Farber of the _[New York Daily
News](/wiki/Daily_News_\(New_York\) "Daily News \(New York\)")_ also noted the
song's redemptive themes. He said 'Coming Home' is the "only song which breaks
the flow" of _Last Train to Paris_ , "Diddy confesses to everything from bad
parenting to fear of commitment. It's an interesting moment but an unnecessary
one."[14]

Meanwhile, [About.com](/wiki/About.com "About.com")'s Bill Lamb awarded the
song four out of five stars, calling it the first "pop hit single" in a long
time "[which] matches the size of his public persona". He praised the
"beautifully sung chorus by [Skylar Grey](/wiki/Skylar_Grey "Skylar Grey")"
and Diddy's deep "autobiographical lyrics". Lamb noted that the song "didn't
have the same intensity of emotional impact" other [Alex da
Kid](/wiki/Alex_da_Kid "Alex da Kid") productions ([Eminem](/wiki/Eminem
"Eminem")'s "[Love the Way You Lie](/wiki/Love_the_Way_You_Lie "Love the Way
You Lie")") but it did "deliver a warmth and sense of hope that is a good
match with the current holiday season."[3] A reviewer from Sound Savvy said
"The latest single 'Coming Home' is another example of some of the great work
found on the album. ... it’s a heartfelt anthem of triumph and survival –
somber but not depressing."[15]

## Chart
performance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Coming_Home_\(Diddy_%E2%80%93_Dirty_Money_song\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Chart performance")]

"Coming Home" premiered on October 31, 2010, just prior to the fourth game of
the Baseball World Series.[8] It made its U.S. [_Billboard_ Hot
100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100") chart debut at number sixty-
one on December 11, 2010, three weeks after its release.[16] In its third week
on the U.S. _Billboard_ Hot 100, the single experienced a 92% increase in
sales, which amounted to 65,000 copies. As a result, the song vaulted from
number forty-four to number seventeen on the [Digital
Songs](/wiki/Hot_100_Digital_\(Digital_Songs\) "Hot 100 Digital \(Digital
Songs\)") chart causing the single to move from number fifty-one to twenty-
four on the _Billboard_ Hot 100.[17] The song peaked at number seven on the
_Billboard_ Hot Digital Songs chart, number nine on the U.S. [Pop
Songs](/wiki/Mainstream_Top_40_\(Pop_Songs\) "Mainstream Top 40 \(Pop
Songs\)"), number seven on the [Canadian Hot 100](/wiki/Canadian_Hot_100
"Canadian Hot 100") chart, and number eleven on the _Billboard_ Hot 100 chart.
It also peaked at number fifteen on the Radio Songs. Consequently, "Coming
Home" outperformed all of the group's previous singles on the Hot 100 and
Digital Songs charts.[18] Additionally, "Coming Home" also peaked higher than
two of the three songs mentioned in the lyrics. "[Ain't No Stoppin' Us
Now](/wiki/Ain%27t_No_Stoppin%27_Us_Now "Ain't No Stoppin' Us Now")" by
[McFadden & Whitehead](/wiki/McFadden_%26_Whitehead "McFadden & Whitehead")
reached number thirteen, while [Dionne Warwick](/wiki/Dionne_Warwick "Dionne
Warwick")'s "[A House Is Not a Home](/wiki/A_House_Is_Not_a_Home_\(song\) "A
House Is Not a Home \(song\)")" only reached number seventy-nine.[10] The song
experience some crossover success, including on the [Rap
Songs](/wiki/Rap_Songs "Rap Songs") chart where it reached number twenty-
one.[19] By the end of January 2011, "Coming Home" had sold one million
digital copies in the United States.[10] It was certified
[platinum](/wiki/List_of_music_recording_certifications "List of music
recording certifications") by the [Recording Industry Association of
America](/wiki/Recording_Industry_Association_of_America "Recording Industry
Association of America") (RIAA) on April 19 and 2× platinum on May 17,
2011.[20]

Internationally, the single got off to a strong start in Belgium, debuting on
both the [Flanders Tip](/wiki/Ultratip "Ultratip") and Wallonia Tip charts at
number twenty-six.[21][22] "Coming Home" would later top both Tip charts,
before impacting on the main [Ultratop](/wiki/Ultratop "Ultratop")
charts.[23][24] On the Flanders Ultratop Singles chart, the song peaked at
number seventeen, while on the Wallonia chart it peaked at number twenty-
seven.[25][26] "Coming Home" debuted in Switzerland at number forty-eight, and
dropped seven places to number fifty-five in its second week.[27] In its third
week, the single rose fifteen places to number forty, and then continued to
rise, eventually reaching number one on the [Swiss Singles
Chart](/wiki/Swiss_Singles_Chart "Swiss Singles Chart").[28] As a result of
reaching number one, "Coming Home" is Diddy's highest charting single in
Switzerland in fourteen years; his last number one in Switzerland was "[I'll
Be Missing You](/wiki/I%27ll_Be_Missing_You "I'll Be Missing You")" with
[Faith Evans](/wiki/Faith_Evans "Faith Evans") and [112](/wiki/112_\(band\)
"112 \(band\)") in 1997.[29] "Coming Home" made its [Australian Singles
Chart](/wiki/ARIA_Charts "ARIA Charts") debut at number forty-nine and is thus
the first single from Diddy-Dirty Money to chart within the top-fifty.[30] It
is since peaked at number four, and number two on the Australian Urban Singles
Chart.[30][31] The single had equal success in Germany, peaking at number four
for two weeks.[32]

"Coming Home" was also successful in other territories too, also peaking in
the top-ten in Austria, France, Ireland, New Zealand and
Poland.[33][34][35][36][37] On December 15, 2010 the single was added to the
playlists on British [mainstream](/wiki/BBC_Radio_1 "BBC Radio 1") radio[38]
and a week later to the playlists on British [urban
music](/wiki/BBC_Radio_1Xtra "BBC Radio 1Xtra") radio.[39] Following its
release, "Coming Home" debuted at number four on the [UK Singles
Chart](/wiki/UK_Singles_Chart "UK Singles Chart"), becoming Diddy's most
successful single in that country since 2006's "[Come to
Me](/wiki/Come_to_Me_\(Diddy_song\) "Come to Me \(Diddy song\)")" with [Nicole
Scherzinger](/wiki/Nicole_Scherzinger "Nicole Scherzinger").[40][41]
Additionally the single topped the [UK R&B Chart](/wiki/UK_R%26B_Chart "UK R&B
Chart") and as a consequence, "Coming Home" is Diddy-Dirty Money's most
successful single in the United Kingdom.[42][43] In its second week, the
single held on to its position of number four on the singles chart, which came
in addition to maintaining its position at the top of the UK R&B Singles chart
for three consecutive weeks.[44][45] According to a press release by
[Interscope Records](/wiki/Interscope_Records "Interscope Records"), as of
March 25, 2011, "Coming Home" has sold 1.8 million digital downloads
worldwide.[46]

## Music
video[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Coming_Home_\(Diddy_%E2%80%93_Dirty_Money_song\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Music video")]

###
Background[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Coming_Home_\(Diddy_%E2%80%93_Dirty_Money_song\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Background")]

The accompanying [music video](/wiki/Music_video "Music video") made its
worldwide premiere through [E! Online](/wiki/E! "E!") on November 29, 2010. It
was filmed entirely in the Mojave Desert, just outside Palm Springs, CA.[47]
The video was the first of three released in the three weeks counting down to
the album's release. Album cuts "Somebody to Love Me" and "[Ass on the
Floor](/wiki/Ass_on_the_Floor "Ass on the Floor")" (featuring [Swizz
Beatz](/wiki/Swizz_Beatz "Swizz Beatz")) received video releases on December
10 and December 13, respectively.[48][49] "Coming Home" was directed by [Rich
Lee](/wiki/Rich_Lee "Rich Lee") and according to Steven Gottlieb, of Video
Static, the theme drew comparisons to some of Diddy's earliest work. "'Coming
Home' has Diddy choppering onto a dry lake bed which is dotted by the charred
remains of a luxurious lifestyle."[50]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c7/Coming_Home.jpg/275px-
Coming_Home.jpg)](/wiki/File:Coming_Home.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Coming_Home.jpg "Enlarge")

A scene from the middle of the video, where Diddy enters the burnt remains of
a home, while singing about moments of his life. The two female members of the
group, (Dawn and Kalenna) walk the landscape outside.

###
Synopsis[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Coming_Home_\(Diddy_%E2%80%93_Dirty_Money_song\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Synopsis")]

"Coming Home" starts with scenes of a black helicopter flying over the desert.
In some of the shots, Diddy can be seen looking out on to the horizon. As the
song progresses into its main verses, the camera follows Diddy walking through
the desert. In the background and foreground, the fire-damaged remnants of a
home such as a TV set, fur coats and a stereo system are scattered across the
landscape. During the chorus [Dawn Richard](/wiki/Dawn_Richard_\(singer\)
"Dawn Richard \(singer\)") and [Kalenna Harper](/wiki/Kalenna_Harper "Kalenna
Harper") take place in front of the camera, walking behind Diddy miming Grey's
words. Later in the clip, during the second verse, Diddy sits in a burned out
building singing to himself. Outside, a burned out vehicle is parked. Then
during the song's [bridge](/wiki/Bridge_\(music\) "Bridge \(music\)"), red
smoke surrounds Diddy as the helicopter, from the opening scene, comes to
land. However, this time Richard and Harper are seated inside waiting for
Diddy. As the song fades, the helicopter flies over the desert toward the
horizon.[51]

###
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Coming_Home_\(Diddy_%E2%80%93_Dirty_Money_song\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Reception")]

Staff from [E! Online](/wiki/E! "E!") seemed impressed with the video's
concept and choice of background scenery. They said "what better place for
some introspection than the desert, right? No sexy bikini-clad ladies or blue-
haired [Nicki Minajs](/wiki/Nicki_Minaj "Nicki Minaj") to distract you, and
when you're done, just call up the helicopter to pick you up (Pro tip: Hang
your leg outside of the chopper for extra cool points.)".[47] Stephen Gottlieb
from Video Static said "It's a nice bookend with Diddy's – then Puff Daddy –
first solo video, "[Can't Nobody Hold Me
Down](/wiki/Can%27t_Nobody_Hold_Me_Down "Can't Nobody Hold Me Down")," which
featured him and [Mase](/wiki/Mase "Mase") introducing an era of big budget
hip-hop while driving a Rolls convertible across the desert."[50] While Ed
Easton Jr. from 92.3 Now FM drew comparisons to Diddy's earlier video for his
1997 hit single "[Been Around the World](/wiki/Been_Around_the_World "Been
Around the World")", thus awarding the video six out of ten. However Easton
was annoyed with the number of videos being released and said that fans were
waiting for the actual album to be released.[52]

## Live performances and usage in
media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Coming_Home_\(Diddy_%E2%80%93_Dirty_Money_song\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Live performances and usage in media")]

Diddy-Dirty Money performed the song live for the first time at the 2010
[American Music Awards](/wiki/American_Music_Awards "American Music Awards")
on November 21, 2010. For the performance the group were joined on stage by a
full orchestra, with Diddy dressed in all-black but the other half of the
group dressed in white gowns.[53] The group reprised this performance on the
December 4, 2010 airing of _[Saturday Night Live](/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live
"Saturday Night Live")_ along with the debut performance of the next scheduled
single "Ass On the Floor".[54] On December 14, 2010 the group performed
"Coming Home" on two separate occasions. First Diddy appeared on daytime
chatshow, _[The View](/wiki/The_View_\(U.S._TV_series\) "The View \(U.S. TV
series\)")_ , for an interview and was then joined by Richard and Harper to
perform "Coming Home"[55] then later the trio performed on the _[Late Show
with David Letterman](/wiki/Late_Show_with_David_Letterman "Late Show with
David Letterman")_.[56] Four days later, the group performed the ballad at the
_WWE Tribute to the Troops_ concert.[57] On January 20, 2011, the group
performed the song live in the United Kingdom, on the _[Radio 1 Live
Lounge](/wiki/Radio_1_Live_Lounge "Radio 1 Live Lounge")_.[11] Diddy-Dirty
Money then returned to the United States, where they performed "Coming Home"
for the first time with [Skylar Grey](/wiki/Skylar_Grey "Skylar Grey"), on
[season ten](/wiki/American_Idol_\(season_10\) "American Idol \(season 10\)")
of _[American Idol](/wiki/American_Idol "American Idol")_ , on March 10,
2011.[58]

The song was used as entrance music by UFC Light Heavyweight champion Jon
Bones Jones before his successful title defense against Quinton Rampage
Jackson. Also, during the pre-game introductions for the [New York
Knicks](/wiki/New_York_Knicks "New York Knicks")' [2010-11
NBA](/wiki/2011-12_NBA_season "2011-12 NBA season") game against the Milwaukee
Bucks on February 23, 2011 (and home debut of newly acquired [Syracuse
Orange](/wiki/Syracuse_Orange "Syracuse Orange") alumnus [Carmelo
Anthony](/wiki/Carmelo_Anthony "Carmelo Anthony")), the song was used in a
pre-game video, welcoming Melo "home" (he started his NBA career with the
[Denver Nuggets](/wiki/Denver_Nuggets "Denver Nuggets") after leaving the
Orange) to New York. There is also a friendly version of the song recorded by
the cast of [Nickelodeon](/wiki/Nickelodeon_\(TV_channel\) "Nickelodeon \(TV
channel\)")'s popular TV show _[iCarly](/wiki/ICarly "ICarly")_ , which can be
heard on the show's second soundtrack, entitled _[iSoundtrack
II](/wiki/ISoundtrack_II "ISoundtrack II")_. It was the official theme song to
[WWE](/wiki/WWE "WWE")'s [WrestleMania 29](/wiki/WrestleMania_29 "WrestleMania
29"), and at the event, Sean Combs and Skylar Grey performed it live in front
of a sold out venue of 80,676 in [MetLife Stadium](/wiki/MetLife_Stadium
"MetLife Stadium").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Though not used as the official theme song,
"Coming Home" has been used in almost every advertisement for the
[ABC](/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company "American Broadcasting Company")
drama series _[Resurrection](/wiki/Resurrection_\(U.S._TV_series\)
"Resurrection \(U.S. TV series\)")_. On December 4, 2013, _[The Fast and the
Furious](/wiki/The_Fast_and_the_Furious "The Fast and the Furious")_ team
released a tribute video to [Paul Walker](/wiki/Paul_Walker "Paul Walker")
after the actor's untimely death, which contained excerpts from _Coming Home_.
On December 30, 2014 newly hired [Michigan
Wolverines](/wiki/Michigan_Wolverines "Michigan Wolverines") head
[football](/wiki/American_football "American football")
[coach](/wiki/Coach_\(sport\) "Coach \(sport\)") [Jim
Harbaugh](/wiki/Jim_Harbaugh "Jim Harbaugh") was introduced to the public
during a brief halftime ceremony with the song playing as he walked onto
center court.[59] On October 28, 2014, an instrumental was a part of the
[Cleveland Cavaliers](/wiki/Cleveland_Cavaliers "Cleveland Cavaliers") pre-
game introductions as it was the first game back in Cleveland for [LeBron
James](/wiki/LeBron_James "LeBron James") since 2010. The song was used in a
video by the [Los Angeles Rams](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Rams "Los Angeles Rams")
announcing their return to Los Angeles after more than two decades in St.
Louis. As [Dwyane Wade](/wiki/Dwyane_Wade "Dwyane Wade") returned to his
hometown of Chicago in 2016, a video using the song was created to mark the
occasion.
